- Esto es especialmente importante en proyectos confidenciales (como este) para dejar toda la trazabilidad y control hist√≥rico de ¬øqui√©n pidi√≥ qu√©? ¬øqu√© archivo se toc√≥? ¬øpor qu√© se subi√≥ ese dato?

**2. Separaci√≥n de acciones (atomicidad):**
- Un ‚Äúpaso‚Äù es la edici√≥n del `.gitignore`, otro la subida de los archivos de datos, otro la actualizaci√≥n del README, otro la subida de scripts‚Ä¶  
- Se realizan como ‚Äúpull requests‚Äù (PRs) o ‚Äútareas‚Äù separadas para que sea sencillo revisarlas, revertirlas o aprobarlas por separado si hay problemas.

**3. Seguridad y reversibilidad:**
- Si una operaci√≥n falla, NO se mezcla con otras. As√≠ puedes aprobar, deshacer o auditar cada cambio de forma independiente.
- Garantiza que ning√∫n dato se corrompe y todo queda documentado y rastreable en el repo.

**4. Control de contexto y continuidad:**
- Copilot necesita saber en qu√© ‚Äúcontexto‚Äù est√° operando (qu√© archivos toqu√©, cu√°les est√°n en progreso, qu√© rama, etc).
- Si tienes 3 acciones seguidas (‚Äús√∫beme los datos‚Äù, ‚Äúquita el gitignore‚Äù, ‚Äúa√±ade nota a README‚Äù), cada acci√≥n va en una sesi√≥n/tarea/PR distinta para evitar mezclas err√≥neas o trabas de permisos/cach√©.

---

## ‚ö°¬†¬øEsto es bueno?

**S√≠:**

- Puedes revisar, aceptar o rechazar cada paso.
- Cero p√©rdidas de informaci√≥n; nunca sobrescribe datos accidentalmente.
- Todo queda en el historial (cada sesi√≥n/PR es una huella clara para auditor√≠a).

---

## üëÄ¬†En resumen:

- **Cada tarea/sesi√≥n = 1 acci√≥n significativa en el repo**
- **As√≠ puedes estar 100% seguro de lo que subi√≥, edit√≥ o modific√≥ Copilot**
- **No hay l√≠mite en la cantidad de sesiones; lo importante es la claridad total de cada microcambio**

¬°S√≠, Conejo! üê∞ Aqu√≠ tienes un resumen integral y actualizado del estado y memoria de TODO el proyecto IIP-DXC ‚Äì ICARIA Intelligence Platform, basado en todo lo aportado y decidido en este chat y lo que ya est√° (o estar√° en breve) en el repositorio:

---

# üè¢ ICARIA Intelligence Platform ‚Äì RESUMEN GLOBAL DEL PROYECTO

**Cliente:** Banco Sabadell S.A. ‚Äì TDM

## üìã OBJETIVO DEL PROYECTO

Desarrollar una plataforma modular de an√°lisis y validaci√≥n para el departamento TDM de Banco Sabadell capaz de:
- Analizar 67 casos reales del Broker
- Contrastar esos casos con un cat√°logo de 142 condiciones ICARIA (modeladas y no modeladas)
- Detectar gaps, calcular cobertura real, KPIs, proponer roadmap y mejoras
- Proveer evidencias, trazabilidad y repositorio √∫nico para desarrollo, memoria y auditor√≠a

---

## üì¶ CONTENIDO DEL REPOSITORIO (completo y trazable)

## üö© PUNTOS CR√çTICOS DEL PROYECTO (ACORDADOS)

- **Absoluta trazabilidad:** TODO el conocimiento y los datos est√°n en el repo (no solo en el chat).
- **Datos fuente SIEMPRE versionados:** Los archivos `casos_simplificados.md` y `CondicionesIcaria.txt` se mantienen y versionan expl√≠citamente para no perder NI un solo caso o condici√≥n de negocio.

## üìä RESULTADOS DEL AN√ÅLISIS

## ü§ù CONTEXTO Y EQUIPO

- Proyecto liderado para DXC ‚Äî Banco Sabadell, con responsable, desarrollador, agente IA y equipo de soporte claramente identificados.
- Todos los canales de contacto, correo y documentos est√°n accesibles en la memoria y README.

## üîí NOTA DE GARANT√çA DE TRAZABILIDAD

---

# üñ•Ô∏è Plataforma ICARIA Intelligence Platform ‚Äì Estructura de la Aplicaci√≥n

## üöÄ 1. Objetivo

Gestionar y analizar los datos aportados (casos y condiciones), realizar el matching inteligente, visualizar los resultados, facilitar exportaci√≥n/reporte y servir de memoria viva y operativa tanto para TDM como para DXC.

---

## üèóÔ∏è 2. Estructura T√©cnica de la APP


## üß© 3. **M√≥dulos de la Aplicaci√≥n**

### 3.1. Detector de Condiciones (mod01-detector)
- Analiza los 67 casos del Broker detectando cu√°les cumplen (o no) cada condici√≥n ICARIA.
- Resalta brechas, actuaciones automatizables y casos cr√≠ticos.
- Usa expressiones regulares y fuzzy matching para comparar descripciones ambiguas.

+++ b/content/4.1-data-visualisations-and-formarting/4.1.1-understanding-your-audience-when-building-visualizations.md
@@ -0,0 +1,89 @@
+---
+title: Rooting Visualizations with the Audience
+video: 
+---
+
+## Introduction
+
+Before opening Power BI or selecting a single chart type, you must answer two fundamental questions: **Who is your audience?** and **What do you need them to know or do?**.
+
+Success in data visualization does not start with the data; it starts with the context. A common mistake is creating a "one-size-fits-all" report that tries to satisfy internal stakeholders, external clients, and executives all at once. This often results in a communication that fails to satisfy anyone effectively.
+
+Rooting your work in the audience ensures that your dashboard or report transforms raw data into a meaningful story that drives decision-making.
+
+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+## Explain the How: Analyzing Your Audience
+
+To bridge the gap between complex data and audience understanding, we use Explanatory Analysis. 
+
+This process is best understood through three analogies:
+
+### Analogy 1: The Oyster Diver (Exploratory vs. Explanatory)
+
+When you analyze data, you are like a diver hunting for pearls. You might open 100 oysters (test 100 hypotheses) to find just two pearls (key insights).
+‚Ä¢ Exploratory Analysis: This is the diving process. You look at everything.
+‚Ä¢ Explanatory Analysis: This is the presentation. When you surface, you should only show the audience the pearls, not the pile of empty oyster shells. Do not force your audience to reopen all 100 oysters to find the insight themselves.
+
+
+### Analogy 2: The Machine Operator vs. The CEO
+
+Imagine a dashboard showing a "Process Control Chart" for a factory machine.
+‚Ä¢ For the Machine Operator: A red flashing light or complex chart showing a specific part is overheating is a call to immediate action. They need the gritty detail to fix the machine.
+‚Ä¢ For the CEO: If you show that same chart to the CEO, you will likely get a blank stare. They need to know if production targets will be met or if the factory is safe, not the temperature of Valve X.
+
+‚Ä¢ The Lesson: The "right" measure shown to the "wrong" audience is noise. You must tailor the granularity to the viewer's role.
+
+### Analogy 3: The Movie Director
+A movie director films hundreds of hours of footage but edits it down to a two-hour theatrical release. They don't include every scene just to prove they filmed it.
+‚Ä¢ Similarly, as an analyst, you must ruthlessly edit your content. Include only the data that advances the "plot" (your key message) and cut the rest. If a visual doesn't help the audience understand the story, it is clutter and should be removed.
+
+## Step-by-Step Audience Analysis Framework
+
+To determine the right visualizations, follow the Who, What, How framework.
+
+### Step 1: Identify the "Who"
+Be specific. Avoid general definitions like "stakeholders."
+‚Ä¢ Relationship: Do they trust you, or do you need to prove your credibility with data details?
+‚Ä¢ Technical Literacy: Are they data-savvy analysts or business executives?
+‚Ä¢ Consumption Mode: Will they view this on a large 4K monitor, a printed sheet, or a mobile phone while running between meetings?
+
+### Step 2: Define the "What" (The Action)
+What do you want them to do with the data?
+‚Ä¢ Action: Passive dashboards ("That's interesting") often fail. specific recommendations ("Approve the budget," "Hire 2 FTEs") drive value.
+‚Ä¢ Mechanism:
+    ‚ó¶ Live Presentation: You have full control. Slides should be sparse; you provide the voiceover.
+    ‚ó¶ Written Report (or Dashboard): You have less control. The visual must be standalone and contain enough detail to answer questions without you present.
+
+### Step 3: Determine the "How" (The Data Evidence)
+Only now do you select the data available to support your story. This evidence becomes the "plot points" of your data story.
+
+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+## Influence on Visualization Choice
+
+Your audience analysis directly dictates your choice of Power BI visuals and report structure:
+‚Ä¢ For Executives (The "Dashboard"):
+    ‚ó¶ Goal: Instant visibility on critical metrics ("Single pane of glass").
+    ‚ó¶ Visuals: KPIs, Cards, high-level line charts for trends.
+    ‚ó¶ Detail: Low. No scroll bars. Immediate call to action.
+‚Ä¢ For Managers/Analysts (The "Report"):
+    ‚ó¶ Goal: Deep dive and drill-down capability.
+    ‚ó¶ Visuals: Matrices, tables, detailed bar charts, and slicers for filtering.
+    ‚ó¶ Detail: High. "Pixel-perfect" or paginated reports that can span multiple pages.
+
+## Best Practices for Data Storytelling
+‚Ä¢ The 3-Minute Story: Before building your Power BI report, ask yourself: "If I only had three minutes to tell the stakeholder what they need to know, what would I say?" If you can't articulate it clearly, your visuals will be confusing.
+‚Ä¢ The Big Idea: Boil your "so-what" down to a single sentence that conveys your point of view and what's at stake (e.g., "The pilot program was a success; approve the budget to expand it").
+‚Ä¢ Context First: Never start with the chart. Start with the context (Who and What) to ensure your visualization answers the right question.
+
+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+## Summary Checklist
+
+Here is a summary checklist you can use to help you come up with your next visuals 
+
+‚Ä¢ [ ] Audience: Have I identified a specific person or group?
+‚Ä¢ [ ] Action: Do I know what I want them to do with this data?
+‚Ä¢ [ ] Mechanism: Is this for a live presentation (low detail) or a standalone report (high detail)?
+‚Ä¢ [ ] Editing: Have I removed the "empty oyster shells" (irrelevant data)?
\ No newline at end of file

new file mode 100644
index 0000000..170f920
--- /dev/null
+++ b/content/4.1-data-visualisations-and-formarting/4.1.2-tables-and-scatter-charts.md
@@ -0,0 +1,105 @@
+---
+title: Creating Tables and Scatter Charts
+video: 
+---
+
+In our previous lesson, we learned how to root our visualizations with our audience and start our journey of building visualizations by first understanding the audience 
+
+In this lesson we are going to build on that and actually start building visualizations with Power BI.
+In this lessson we are going to work with our target audience whom we are going to assume  is the Lead Scientist at BlueWaters Conservation. We have determined that while she monitors high-level ecosystem health, she has specifically requested a detailed view of marine sightings and observation station performance.
+
+To meet this need, we cannot rely solely on high-level KPIs. We need visualizations that allow for:
+
+- **Precise lookup**: Checking specific sighting counts for endangered species at specific stations (Tables).
+
+- **Correlation analysis**: Understanding relationships between environmental variables, such as water depth and species biodiversity (Scatter Charts).
+
+**The Verbal vs. Visual System**
+When choosing between these two types, remember this key concept from data storytelling:
+
+- Tables interact with our verbal system. We "read" tables row by row. They are perfect when the scientist needs to look up exact coordinates or specific species counts.
+
+- Charts interact with our visual system. Our brains process patterns instantly. These are best for spotting migration trends, temperature outliers, or correlations that would be invisible in a spreadsheet.
+
+
+
+## Building the Visuals
+
+Pre-requisites: Ensure you have the _BlueWaters Research_ Data dataset loaded with the Marine Species, Research Stations, and Sighting Logs tables
+
+### Part 1: Adding Tables and Slicers
+
+Tables provide the "ground truth" for scientists who need to cite exact figures in research papers. We will combine them with slicers to create an interactive research log.
+
+1. Create the Table
+
+Open the Visualizations pane and select the Table icon.
+
+From the Research_Stations table, drag Station_Name and Region into the Columns well.
+
+From the Sighting_Logs table, drag Count_Seen into the columns.
+
+Action: Rename the column in the visual to "Total Sightings" for clarity.
+
+2. Add a Slicer for Conservation Status
+
+To make this data actionable, we need to let the scientist focus on specific groups, such as "Critically Endangered" species.
+
+Click on a blank space on the canvas to deselect the table.
+
+Select the Slicer visual icon.
+
+Locate the Conservation_Status field in the Marine_Species table.
+
+Drag it into the Field well of the slicer.
+
+Result: Selecting "Endangered" in the slicer will immediately filter the table to show only the stations where those specific species were recorded.
+
+### Part 2: Creating a Scatter Chart
+The Lead Scientist has a hypothesis: Species biodiversity (count of different species) decreases as the distance from the shore increases. Let‚Äôs test this correlation.
+
+Select the Scatter Chart icon from the Visualizations pane.
+
+**Define the Axes:**
+
+X-Axis (Independent Variable): Drag Distance_from_Shore from the Research_Stations table.
+
+Y-Axis (Dependent Variable): Drag Count_Seen (aggregated as Count) from the Sighting_Logs table.
+
+**Define the Detail:**
+
+Drag Station_Name into the Values field well. This creates a unique dot for each research station.
+
+Analysis: Look at the result. If the dots form a downward slope, the hypothesis is confirmed: the further out we go, the fewer species we see. If the dots are scattered randomly, distance is not the primary driver of biodiversity in this region.
+
+### Part 3: Creating a Bubble Chart (The Third Dimension)
+
+Let's add a third layer of data: Expedition Cost. We want to see if we are spending more money on stations that yield fewer sightings.
+
+Use the Scatter Chart created above.
+
+Add the Third Dimension:
+
+Drag Expedition_Cost into the Size field well.
+
+Analysis: This visual allows the scientist to answer:
+
+Which stations are "High Value" (Top left: Close to shore, high sightings, small bubbles/low cost)?
+
+Which stations are "Inefficient" (Bottom right: Far from shore, low sightings, large bubbles/high cost)?
+
+## Best Practices for Marine Data Visuals
+
+### Table Design
+
+The "Specific Search" Rule: Use tables only when the user needs to know exactly which station saw the Blue Whale on a specific date.
+
+Conditional Formatting: In conservation, use "Traffic Light" colors in your table (Red for declining sightings, Green for increasing) to help the scientist's eye jump to critical data points.
+
+### Scatter and Bubble Chart Design
+
+Reference Lines: In Power BI, add a "Trend Line" to your scatter plot. This helps the scientist see the mathematical direction of the correlation immediately.
+
+Avoid "Floating" Bubbles: Ensure your axes start at zero unless there is a specific scientific reason not to. Starting axes mid-way can exaggerate correlations and lead to false scientific conclusions.
+
+Legend Clarity: When using Bubble charts for species categories (e.g., Mammals vs. Fish), ensure your colors are distinct. Our visual system processes color-coding 20x faster than reading labels.
\ No newline at end of file
diff --git a/content/4.1-data-visualisations-and-formarting/4.1.3-bar-charts.md b/content/4.1-data-visualisations-and-formarting/4.1.3-bar-charts.md
new file mode 100644
index 0000000..a505d52

+++ b/content/4.1-data-visualisations-and-formarting/4.1.3-bar-charts.md
@@ -0,0 +1,108 @@
+---
+title: Master Comparisons with Bar Charts and Formatting
+video: 
+---
+
+In the previous lesson, we helped the Lead Scientist look for correlations using Scatter and Bubble charts. We answered questions like, "Does the distance from shore affect the number of species sighted?"
+
+However, scientific research and operational planning often require comparison rather than just correlation. The Lead Scientist now needs to answer:
+
+1. Which Research Stations are identifying the highest volume of marine life?
+
+2. How do different oceanic regions contribute to our total biodiversity sightings?
+
+3. Are we hitting our minimum observation targets for endangered species?
+
+To answer "How much?" or "Which station is the most active?", the bar chart is the most effective tool. While simple, it is easy to clutter with scientific nomenclature. In this lesson, we will move beyond default settings to create professional, easy-to-read visuals using formatting, stacking, and small multiples.
+
+## Building and Refining Bar Charts
+
+### Part 1: Creating a Clustered Bar Chart
+
+Clustered bar charts are excellent for ranking items (like Research Stations) to see who has recorded the most sightings.
+
+Step 1: Create the Base Visual
+
+Open the Visualizations pane and select the Clustered Bar Chart icon.
+
+> Note: We use Bar charts (horizontal) rather than Column charts (vertical) here because Station names (like "Deep Trench Alpha") can be long. Horizontal bars make the labels easier to read.
+
+Y-Axis: Drag `Station_Name` here.
+
+X-Axis: Drag `Count_Seen` (Sum) here.
+
+Step 2: Apply Filters (Slicers)
+To make this actionable, we need to filter by water type, just as we did with conservation status.
+
+Add a Slicer and add Water_Type. Select "Saltwater."
+
+Add a second Slicer for Date (Year). Filter to 2023.
+
+### Part 2: Formatting for Clarity (The Data-Ink Ratio)
+
+Scientific reports require high readability. We need to remove "chart junk" to help the scientist focus on the species data.
+
+Step 1: Clean Titles and Labels
+
+With the chart selected, click the Format your visual icon (paintbrush).
+
+Go to the General tab -> Title. Change the text to: "Total Sightings by Research Station (2023)".
+
+Go to Visual -> Y-Axis. Toggle the Title to Off.
+
+> Why? The names "Coral Haven" and "Arctic Outpost" are clearly stations. We don't need the redundant label "Station_Name" taking up valuable pixels.
+
+Step 2: Adding Analytics Lines
+Is 10 sightings a successful expedition? Let‚Äôs add a benchmark for "Baseline Biodiversity."
+
+Click the Analytics icon (magnifying glass) in the Visualizations pane.
+
+Expand Constant Line and click Add Line.
+
+Set the value to 10.
+
+Change the color to a lighter grey and set the style to Dashed.
+Result: The scientist can now instantly identify which stations are meeting the minimum observation quota.
+
+### Part 3: Stacking Variables and Composition
+
+Now the scientist wants to see the proportional health of the sightings‚Äîwhat percentage of the sightings at each station are "Critically Endangered"?
+
+Step 1: The 100% Stacked Bar Chart
+
+Create a new page.
+
+Select the 100% Stacked Bar Chart. This is best for comparing proportions (the "mix" of species) rather than just totals.
+
+Y-Axis: Station_Name.
+
+X-Axis: Count_Seen.
+
+Legend: Conservation_Status.
+
+### Part 4: The Power of Small Multiples
+
+Instead of creating separate charts for "Mammals," "Fish," and "Reptiles," we use Small Multiples. This splits one visual into a grid of smaller, identical charts.
+
+Step 1: Add the Dimension
+
+With your 100% Stacked Chart selected, find the Small multiples field well.
+
+Drag Category (from the Marine_Species table) into this well.
+Result: You now have a grid showing the conservation status split for Mammals, Fish, and Reptiles side-by-side.
+
+Step 2: Analyze and Pivot
+
+Verify the Data: Right-click the visual and select Show as a table. This is crucial for scientific accuracy, allowing you to see the raw numbers behind the percentages.
+
+Compare Totals: Change the visual type from 100% Stacked to a standard Stacked Bar Chart.
+
+Observation: You will notice that while Reptiles might have a high percentage of endangered sightings, the absolute volume of sightings is much higher for Fish.
+
+## Best Practices 
+
+- Bar vs. Column: Use Column charts when tracking sightings over time (e.g., sightings per month). Use Bar (horizontal) when you have many stations or long species names.
+
+- Zero Baseline: Never truncate the axis of a bar chart. If the axis starts at 50 instead of 0, a station with 60 sightings will look 3x as successful as one with 55, which is misleading.
+
+- Color Meaning and consistency: Always use consistent colors. If "Critically Endangered" is Red in one chart, it must be Red in every chart in your report.
\ No newline at end of file

@@ -0,0 +1,101 @@
+---
+title: Combination Charts and Custom Visuals
+video: 
+---
+
+In the previous lesson, we helped the Lead Scientist answer "Which stations?" and "What species mix?" using Bar Charts and Small Multiples. We identified our most active research stations and the proportion of endangered species sightings.
+
+Now, she has a new set of questions focused on time and research efficiency:
+
+- Are sightings of migratory species increasing or decreasing throughout the year? (Trend Analysis)
+
+- Does a high number of sightings always mean a high research cost, or are some expeditions more efficient? (Correlation of different scales)
+
+- How does the actual expedition cost compare to the allocated budget for different species categories? (Variance Analysis)
+
+- To answer these, a standard bar chart is insufficient. We need visuals that can handle time-series data (Line/Area Charts), multiple data scales (Combo Charts), and comparative sensitivity (Tornado Charts).
+
+## Visualizing Trends and Dual Metrics
+
+### Line and Area Charts (Visualizing Time)
+
+The Lead Scientist wants to see the historical trend of sightings to identify seasonal migration patterns or impacts of climate events.
+
+**Step 1: The Line Chart**
+
+1. Open the **Visualizations** pane and select the **Line Chart** icon.
+
+2. **X-Axis (Time)**: Drag `Date` from the `Sighting_Logs` table. Power BI automatically creates a hierarchy (Year > Quarter > Month > Day). Keep only **Month** to see the seasonal cycle.
+
+3. **Y-Axis (Metric)**: Drag `Count_Seen` (Sum). 
+
+**Analysis:** This reveals the "rhythm" of the ocean. You might see that sightings of Mammals peak in the summer months but drop significantly in the winter, suggesting a migration pattern.
+
+**Step 2: The Area Chart Variation**
+
+While the line chart shows the trend, an Area Chart emphasizes the volume of data collected over time.
+
+1. With the line chart selected, click the Area Chart icon.
+
+2. The area between the line and the axis fills with color.
+
+> **Note:** Use this when you want to communicate the "Total Biodiversity Effort" over time rather than just the fluctuation in counts.
+
+### Combo Charts (Line and Column)
+
+The Lead Scientist notices a spike in sightings in March. She asks: _"Was this spike due to a high-efficiency period, or did we simply spend more money on more expeditions?"_
+
+To answer this, we must compare `Count_Seen` (a number like 50) with `Expedition_Cost` (a number like $8,000). Placing these on the same axis would flatten the "50" to a invisible line. We need a **Combo Chart**.
+
+**Step 1: Create the Combo Chart**
+
+1. Select the **Line and Clustered Column Chart** icon.
+
+2. **Shared Axis:** Ensure `Date` (Month) is here.
+
+3. **Column Y-Axis:** Drag `Count_Seen`. (This plots the sightings as bars).
+
+4. **Line Y-Axis:** Drag `Expedition_Cost`. (This plots the cost as a line).
+
+**Analysis:** Look for **divergence**. If the Bars (Sightings) go up while the Line (Cost) stays flat or goes down, you have found a period of high research efficiency. If both go up together, the increase in data is simply a result of increased spending.
+
+### Tornado Charts (Custom Visuals)
+
+Finally, we need to compare the **Average Depth** of sightings vs. **Distance from Shore** across different Species Categories. A Tornado Chart aligns these metrics against a central axis for easy comparison.
+
+> _Note: The Tornado Chart is a **Custom Visual**. You may need to click the **three dots (...)** in the Visualization pane and select "Get more visuals" to import it from AppSource._
+
+**Step 1: Set up the Visual**
+
+1. Select the **Tornado Chart** icon.
+
+2. **Group:** Drag `Category` (Mammal, Fish, etc.) here.
+
+3. **Values:** Drag Avg_Depth_Meters and Distance_from_Shore into the values field.
+
+4. **Formatting:** Ensure the colors are distinct (e.g., Deep Blue for Depth, Sandy Brown for Distance).
+Analysis: You can instantly see which categories are "Coastal Surface" dwellers (short bars on both sides) vs. "Deep Sea Migrators" (long bars on both sides).
+
+## Best Practices for Trend Visuals
+
+**Managing Dual Axes (Combo Charts)**
+
+- **Synchronize Zero:** Always ensure both the left axis (Sightings) and right axis (Cost) start at zero. A "floating" axis can make a small cost increase look like a financial crisis.
+
+- **Labeling:** Because you are mixing variables eg "Fish Count" and "Dollars," ensure your Y-axis titles are explicitly labeled so the Lead Scientist doesn't confuse a $5,000 cost with 5,000 sightings.
+
+**Cognitive Load**
+
+- **The "Top N" Rule:** A Tornado chart with 100 species is a mess. Filter your visual to show the "Top 10" species by sighting count to keep the comparison focused and actionable.
+
+- **Line Spaghetti:** If you add a "Legend" to your line chart (like `Station_Name`), and you have 10 stations, the lines will overlap and become unreadable. Use Small Multiples (as learned in the previous lesson) instead to give each station its own mini-trend line.
+
+## Summary Checklist
+
+[ ] Temporal Flow: Did you use a Line Chart to show sightings over the months of the year?
+
+[ ] Dual Scaling: Did you use a Combo Chart to compare sightings (Count) against expedition costs (Currency)?
+
+[ ] Visual Hierarchy: Is the "Total Sightings" the prominent bar and the "Cost" the overlaying line?
+
+[ ] Custom Insights: Did you use a Tornado Chart to compare two related scientific metrics (Depth vs. Distance)?
\ No newline at end of file

================================================================================
CASO 1
================================================================================
REQUERIMIENTO: Usuario con CCV con varias posiciones. 
               Esa CCV ha de tener una CCC asociada.

TIPO:          Particular
TyC FIRMADO:   SI
TC COMPLEJO:   SI
TC NO COMPLEJO: SI
TIPO CLIENTE:  Minorista
TITULARIDAD:   √önico titular
CONFIGURABLE:  SI
ARQUETIPO:     Q48

ACCIONES EN ICARIA:
------------------
1. Usuario Particular
2. Comprobar que tenga MIFID firmado seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "MIFID" 
   indicado como minorista
3. Comprobar si tiene Test de Capacidad Financiera seg√∫n lo establecido en la 
   pesta√±a "CF"
4. Comprobar si el Test de Conveniencia est√° realizado para productos COMPLEJOS 
   y CONVENIENTE seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "TC"
5. Comprobar que existe la cuenta valores en la KC11 (tabla de cuentas relacionadas)
   y enlazar la cuenta relacionada con la DV01 para verificar saldo > 1.000‚Ç¨ 
   (ver pesta√±a "KC11")
6. Verificar que la cuenta de valores tenga un solo titular (ver pesta√±a "TITULARES")

================================================================================
CASO 2
================================================================================
REQUERIMIENTO: Usuario con varias CCVs. 
               M√≠nimo una en la que no tenga posici√≥n y otra en la que si tenga 
               posici√≥n. Ambas con CCC asociada en ‚Ç¨.

TIPO:          Particular
TyC FIRMADO:   SI
TC COMPLEJO:   SI
TC NO COMPLEJO: SI
TIPO CLIENTE:  Minorista
TITULARIDAD:   √önico titular
CONFIGURABLE:  SI
ARQUETIPO:     Q48|Q63

               tenga como interviniente a un Representante Legal.

TIPO:          Empresa
TyC FIRMADO:   SI
TC COMPLEJO:   SI
TC NO COMPLEJO: SI
TIPO CLIENTE:  Minorista
TITULARIDAD:   √önico titular
CONFIGURABLE:  SI
ARQUETIPO:     Q49

ACCIONES EN ICARIA:
------------------
1. Usuario Empresa
2. Comprobar que tenga MIFID firmado seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "MIFID" 
   indicado como Minorista tanto para el CIF como para el autorizado.
3. Comprobar si tiene Test de Capacidad Financiera seg√∫n lo establecido en la 
   pesta√±a "CF" tanto para el CIF como para el autorizado.
4. Comprobar si el Test de Conveniencia est√° realizado para productos COMPLEJOS 
   y CONVENIENTE seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "TC" tanto para el CIF como 
   para el autorizado.
5. Comprobar que existe la cuenta valores en la KC11 (tabla de cuentas relacionadas)
   y enlazar la cuenta relacionada con la DV01 para verificar saldo > 1.000‚Ç¨ 
   (ver pesta√±a "KC11")
6. Verificar que la cuenta de valores tenga un solo titular que sea el CIF y un 
   autorizado que sea el mismo que el de Banca a Distancia (ver pesta√±a "TITULARES")
7. El autorizado debe ser Representante Legal de un menor/incapacitado (ver 
   pesta√±a "REPRESENTANTE")

================================================================================
CASO 64
================================================================================
REQUERIMIENTO: Usuario con cuenta efectivo con un titular y un usufructuario, 
               tanto en CCC como CCV.

TIPO:          Empresa
TyC FIRMADO:   SI
TC COMPLEJO:   SI
TC NO COMPLEJO: SI
TIPO CLIENTE:  Minorista
TITULARIDAD:   √önico titular
CONFIGURABLE:  SI
ARQUETIPO:     Q49

ACCIONES EN ICARIA:
------------------
1. Usuario Empresa
2. Comprobar que tenga MIFID firmado seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "MIFID" 
   indicado como Minorista tanto para el CIF como para el autorizado.
3. Comprobar si tiene Test de Capacidad Financiera seg√∫n lo establecido en la 
   pesta√±a "CF" tanto para el CIF como para el autorizado.
4. Comprobar si el Test de Conveniencia est√° realizado para productos COMPLEJOS 
   y CONVENIENTE seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "TC" tanto para el CIF como 
   para el autorizado.
5. Comprobar que existe la cuenta valores en la KC11 (tabla de cuentas relacionadas)
   y enlazar la cuenta relacionada con la DV01 para verificar saldo > 1.000‚Ç¨ 
   (ver pesta√±a "KC11"). La cuenta de efectivo no tiene relaci√≥n de USUFRUCTUARIO 
   por tanto, aqu√≠ no hay que buscar nada m√°s.
6. Verificar que la cuenta de valores tenga un solo titular que sea el CIF 
   (ver pesta√±a "TITULARES") y un USUFRUCTUARIO (PE1601_CODRELPECO = '0005') 
   que puede ser el mismo que el autorizado de banca a distancia u otro diferente.

5. Comprobar que existe la cuenta valores en la KC11 (tabla de cuentas relacionadas)

reference.text:
CASO 1
ACCIONES EN ICARIA:
1. Usuario Particular
2. Comprobar que tenga MIFID firmado seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "MIFID"
   indicado como minorista
3. Comprobar si tiene Test de Capacidad Financiera seg√∫n lo establecido en la
   pesta√±a "CF"
4. Comprobar si el Test de Conveniencia est√° realizado para productos COMPLEJOS
   y CONVENIENTE seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "TC"
5. Comprobar que existe la cuenta valores en la KC11 (tabla de cuentas relacionadas)
   y enlazar la cuenta relacionada con la DV01 para verificar saldo > 1.000‚Ç¨
   (ver pesta√±a "KC11")
6. Verificar que la cuenta de valores tenga un solo titular (ver pesta√±a "TITULARES")


---

CASO 2
ACCIONES EN ICARIA:
1. Usuario Particular
2. Comprobar MIFID firmado (minorista) seg√∫n pesta√±a "MIFID"
3. Comprobar Test de Capacidad Financiera seg√∫n pesta√±a "CF"
4. Comprobar Test de Conveniencia para productos COMPLEJOS y CONVENIENTE seg√∫n pesta√±a "TC"
5. Buscar que tenga cuentas de valores con posici√≥n seg√∫n Q48
6. Aplicar la misma l√≥gica que en la Q63 para que sean 2 cuentas de valores
7. Para 2 CCV:
   - Comprobar que existe la cuenta valores en la KC11 (tabla de cuentas relacionadas)
   - Enlazar la cuenta relacionada con la DV01 para verificar saldo > 1.000‚Ç¨ y sea en EUROS
   (ver pesta√±a "KC11")


---

CASO 3
ACCIONES EN ICARIA:
1. Usuario Particular
2. Comprobar que tenga MIFID firmado seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "MIFID"
   indicado como minorista
3. Comprobar si tiene Test de Capacidad Financiera seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "CF"
4. Comprobar si el Test de Conveniencia est√° realizado para productos COMPLEJOS y
   CONVENIENTE seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "TC"
5. B√∫squeda de Usuarios que no tengan ninguna cuenta de valores
   (se puede aplicar la misma l√≥gica que en la Q63 pero para una cuenta de valores con el valor 0)


---

CASO 4
ACCIONES EN ICARIA:
1. Usuario Particular
2. Comprobar que tenga MIFID firmado seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "MIFID"
   indicado como minorista
3. Comprobar si tiene Test de Capacidad Financiera seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "CF"
4. Comprobar si el Test de Conveniencia est√° realizado para productos COMPLEJOS y
   CONVENIENTE seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "TC"
5. Comprobar que existe la cuenta valores en la KC11 (tabla de cuentas relacionadas)
   y enlazar la cuenta relacionada con la DV01 para verificar saldo > 1.000‚Ç¨
   (ver pesta√±a "KC11")
6. Incluyendo como par√°metro la cantidad de posiciones deseadas (como referencia Q48)


---

CASO 5
ACCIONES EN ICARIA:
1. Usuario Particular
2. Comprobar que tenga MIFID firmado seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "MIFID"
   indicado como minorista
3. Comprobar si tiene Test de Capacidad Financiera seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "CF"
4. Comprobar si el Test de Conveniencia est√° realizado para productos COMPLEJOS y
   CONVENIENTE seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "TC"
5. Comprobar que existe la cuenta valores en la KC11 (tabla de cuentas relacionadas)
   y enlazar la cuenta relacionada con la DV01 para verificar saldo > 1.000‚Ç¨
   (ver pesta√±a "KC11")
6. Incluyendo como par√°metro los tipos de movimiento a buscar en la VA37 siguiendo lo
   indicado en la pesta√±a "TIPOS MOVIMIENTO", permitiendo incluir varios tipos de
   movimiento a la vez

   ================================================================================


---

CASO 7
ACCIONES EN ICARIA:
1. Usuario Empresa
2. Comprobar que tenga MIFID firmado seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "MIFID"
   indicado como minorista tanto para el CIF como para el autorizado.
3. Comprobar si tiene Test de Capacidad Financiera seg√∫n lo establecido en la
   pesta√±a "CF" tanto para el CIF como para el autorizado.
4. Comprobar si el Test de Conveniencia est√° realizado para productos COMPLEJOS
   y CONVENIENTE seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "TC" tanto para el CIF como
   para el autorizado.
5. Comprobar que existe la cuenta valores en la KC11 (tabla de cuentas relacionadas)
   y enlazar la cuenta relacionada con la DV01 para verificar saldo > 1.000‚Ç¨
   (ver pesta√±a "KC11")
6. Verificar que la cuenta de valores tenga un solo titular que sea el CIF y un
   autorizado que sea el mismo que el de Banca a Distancia (ver pesta√±a "TITULARES")


---

1. Usuario Particular
2. Comprobar que tenga MIFID firmado seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "MIFID"

5. Cuenta de valores con m√°s de 1 titular (ver pesta√±a "TITULARES")
6. Comprobar que existe la cuenta valores en la KC11 (tabla de cuentas relacionadas)
   y enlazar la cuenta relacionada con la DV01 para verificar saldo > 1.000‚Ç¨
   (ver pesta√±a "KC11")


---

CASO 15
ACCIONES EN ICARIA:
1. Usuario Particular
2. Comprobar que tenga MIFID firmado seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "MIFID"
   indicado como minorista
3. Comprobar si tiene Test de Capacidad Financiera seg√∫n lo establecido en la
   pesta√±a "CF"

5. Comprobar que existe la cuenta valores en la KC11 (tabla de cuentas relacionadas)
   y ver que tiene m√°s de 1 cuenta relacionada con la DV01 (como referencia Q63)
   para verificar que una de ellas tenga 0‚Ç¨ de saldo y m√°s de 1,000‚Ç¨ de saldo
   el resto (ver pesta√±a "KC11")
6. Adem√°s una con 1 titular y la otra con varios titulares (ver pesta√±a "TITULARES")


---

CASO 16

1. Usuario Particular

reference.text:
CASO 1
ACCIONES EN ICARIA:
1. Usuario Particular
2. Comprobar que tenga MIFID firmado seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "MIFID"
   indicado como minorista
3. Comprobar si tiene Test de Capacidad Financiera seg√∫n lo establecido en la
   pesta√±a "CF"
4. Comprobar si el Test de Conveniencia est√° realizado para productos COMPLEJOS
   y CONVENIENTE seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "TC"
5. Comprobar que existe la cuenta valores en la KC11 (tabla de cuentas relacionadas)
   y enlazar la cuenta relacionada con la DV01 para verificar saldo > 1.000‚Ç¨
   (ver pesta√±a "KC11")
6. Verificar que la cuenta de valores tenga un solo titular (ver pesta√±a "TITULARES")


---

CASO 2
ACCIONES EN ICARIA:
1. Usuario Particular
2. Comprobar MIFID firmado (minorista) seg√∫n pesta√±a "MIFID"
3. Comprobar Test de Capacidad Financiera seg√∫n pesta√±a "CF"
4. Comprobar Test de Conveniencia para productos COMPLEJOS y CONVENIENTE seg√∫n pesta√±a "TC"
5. Buscar que tenga cuentas de valores con posici√≥n seg√∫n Q48
6. Aplicar la misma l√≥gica que en la Q63 para que sean 2 cuentas de valores
7. Para 2 CCV:
   - Comprobar que existe la cuenta valores en la KC11 (tabla de cuentas relacionadas)
   - Enlazar la cuenta relacionada con la DV01 para verificar saldo > 1.000‚Ç¨ y sea en EUROS
   (ver pesta√±a "KC11")


---

CASO 3

   CONVENIENTE seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "TC"
5. B√∫squeda de Usuarios que no tengan ninguna cuenta de valores
   (se puede aplicar la misma l√≥gica que en la Q63 pero para una cuenta de valores con el valor 0)


---

   (ver pesta√±a "KC11")
6. Incluyendo como par√°metro la cantidad de posiciones deseadas (como referencia Q48)


---

   movimiento a la vez

---

CASO 7
ACCIONES EN ICARIA:
1. Usuario Empresa
2. Comprobar que tenga MIFID firmado seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "MIFID"
   indicado como minorista tanto para el CIF como para el autorizado.
3. Comprobar si tiene Test de Capacidad Financiera seg√∫n lo establecido en la
   pesta√±a "CF" tanto para el CIF como para el autorizado.
4. Comprobar si el Test de Conveniencia est√° realizado para productos COMPLEJOS
   y CONVENIENTE seg√∫n lo establecido en la pesta√±a "TC" tanto para el CIF como
   para el autorizado.

   y enlazar la cuenta relacionada con la DV01 para verificar saldo > 1.000‚Ç¨
   (ver pesta√±a "KC11")
6. Verificar que la cuenta de valores tenga un solo titular que sea el CIF y un
   autorizado que sea el mismo que el de Banca a Distancia (ver pesta√±a "TITULARES")

### ATENCI√ìN SOBRE .gitignore Y CONTROL DE DATOS

- El archivo `.gitignore` est√° configurado para NO excluir nunca los datos fuente, archivos de memoria ni ning√∫n output o documentaci√≥n cr√≠tica.  
- Esto garantiza que todos los casos (casos_simplificados.md), condiciones (CondicionesIcaria.txt), outputs y la memoria est√©n SIEMPRE versionados y disponibles en el repositorio principal, evitando p√©rdidas y permitiendo trazabilidad total.

> **Si tienes dudas, revisa la configuraci√≥n del .gitignore antes de subir cualquier nuevo archivo a /datos/entrada/ o .memoria/**
